case_name: Bakshish Singh v. State of Punjab

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 205 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 30th November, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Crimi- nal Appeal No. 282 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar in Sessions Case No. 64 of Trial No. 6 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 30th November 1955 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 282 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 30th November, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Crimi- nal Appeal No. 282 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar in Sessions Case No. 64 of Trial No. 6 of 1955. L. Anand, and S. N. Anand, for the appellant.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated 15th February 1955 of Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar in Sessions Case No. 64 of Trial No. 6 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar in Sessions Case No. 64 of Trial No. 6 of 1955. L. Anand, and S. N. Anand, for the appellant. Kartar Singh Chawla, Assistant Advocate-General, for the State of Punjab and T. M. Sen, for the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant Bakshish Singh and his brother Gurbakshi Singh were tried for offence under sections 302/34 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Bakshish Singh and his brother Gurbakshi Singh were tried for an offence under ss. 302/34 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted. Against this judgment the State took an appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Bakshish Singh and Gurbakshi Singh were acquitted by Additional Sessions Judge, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: but were acquitted. Against this judgment the State took an appeal to the High Court. As Gurbaksh Singh was said to be ab- sconding the appeal against the appellant alone was heard and decided by the High Court.

facts.text: State appealed against acquittal to Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment the State took an appeal to the High Court. As Gurbaksh Singh was said to be ab- sconding the appeal against the appellant alone was heard and decided by the High Court.

facts.text: Gurbaksh Singh was absconding, so appeal against appellant Bakshish Singh alone was heard by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: As Gurbaksh Singh was said to be ab- sconding the appeal against the appellant alone was heard and decided by the High Court. On August 1, 1954, sometime between 7 and 8 p.m Bachhinder Singh son of Bhagwan Singh of village Kairon was shot in the lane in front of their house

facts.text: On August 1, 1954, between 7 and 8 p.m., Bachhinder Singh son of Bhagwan Singh of village Kairon was shot in the lane in front of their house.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1954, sometime between 7 and 8 p.m Bachhinder Singh son of Bhagwan Singh of village Kairon was shot in the lane in front of their house and as a result of bullet injuries be died the next day in the hospital at Amritsar.

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh died the next day in hospital at Amritsar due to bullet injuries.

anchor.surface_text: and as a result of bullet injuries be died the next day in the hospital at Amritsar. He was at the time of shooting accompanied by his younger brother Narvel Singh, a boy of 13, and after getting injured Bachhinder Singh and his brother returned to the house.

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh was accompanied by his younger brother Narvel Singh, aged 13, at the time of shooting.

anchor.surface_text: He was at the time of shooting accompanied by his younger brother Narvel Singh, a boy of 13, and after getting injured Bachhinder Singh and his brother returned to the house. Bhagwan Singh states that he was informed of the identity of the assailants by Bachhinder Singh

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh informed his father Bhagwan Singh of the identity of the assailants after returning to the house.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwan Singh states that he was informed of the identity of the assailants by Bachhinder Singh who was, at his own request, carried from the house to the hospital at Kairon but as the injuries were serious the doctor at Kairon rendered first aid and advised the father to take his son to V. J. Hospital at Amritsar.

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh was taken to hospital at Kairon, received first aid, advised to go to V.J. Hospital Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: who was, at his own request, carried from the house to the hospital at Kairon but as the injuries were serious the doctor at Kairon rendered first aid and advised the father to take his son to V. J. Hospital at Amritsar. Bhagwan Singh then took Bachhinder Singh to the Railway Station

facts.text: Bhagwan Singh went to Police Post at Kairon, about 100 yards from Railway Station, to make report but Assistant Sub-Inspector was away at Sarhali.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwan Singh then took Bachhinder Singh to the Railway Station but before the arrival of the train he went to the Police Post at Kairon which is at a distance of about 100 yds. from the Railway Station in order to make a report. As the Assistant Sub Inspector was away at Sarhali, he returned to the Railway Station

facts.text: Bhagwan Singh took Bachhinder Singh to Amritsar hospital by train leaving Kairon at 9:47 p.m., accompanied by Narvel Singh, Shamir Singh, Inder Singh and Narinjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: and took his son to the Amritsar hospital by the train leaving Kairon at 9-47 p.m. Bhagwan Singh was accompanied at that time by his younger son, Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, and by Shamir Singh, Inder Singh and Narinjan Singh. Soon after their arrival at the Amritsar hospital Bachhinder Singh was examined

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh examined by Dr. Kanwal Kishore at 11:45 p.m. at Amritsar hospital.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after their arrival at the Amritsar hospital Bachhinder Singh was examined by Dr. Kanwal Ki- shore, P.W. 2, at 11-45 p.m. and finding the injury to be of a serious nature the doctor sent information to the Police as a result of which Head Constable Maya Ram Sharma, P.W. 4, arrived at the hospital

facts.text: Head Constable Maya Ram Sharma recorded dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh, Exhibit P-H, after midnight, in presence of Dr. Mahavir Sud.

anchor.surface_text: as a result of which Head Constable Maya Ram Sharma, P.W. 4, arrived at the hospital sometime after midnight and, in the presence of Dr. Mahavir Sud, P.W. 17, recorded the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh, Exhibit P-H, after getting a certificate from the doctor that the injured person was in a fit state to make a statement.

facts.text: First Information Report, Exhibit P-H/1, copy of Exhibit P-H, recorded on August 2, 1954 at 7:50 a.m. at Police Station Sarhali, about 20 miles from Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: This statement is the basis of the First Information Report, Exhibit P-H. 1, which is a companyy of Exhibit P-H. This report was recorded on August 2, 1954, at 7-50 a.m. at Police Station Sarhali which, we were told, is about 20 miles or so away from Amritsar.

facts.text: Dr. K.C. Saronwala performed operation on Bachhinder Singh in early hours of morning and extracted bullet from left abdominal wall, handed to police.

anchor.surface_text: In the early hours of the morning Dr. K. C. Saronwala P.W. I performed an operation on Bachhinder Singh and extracted a bullet from the left abdominal wall which was handed over to the Police. But Bachhinder Singh died at 1-35 p.m. on August 2, 1954.

facts.text: Bachhinder Singh died at 1:35 p.m. on August 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: But Bachhinder Singh died at 1-35 p.m. on August 2, 1954. An inquest report Exhibit P-K was prepared at 2-30 p.m. by Head Constable Maya Ram, P.W. 4.

facts.text: Inquest report Exhibit P-K prepared at 2:30 p.m. by Head Constable Maya Ram.

anchor.surface_text: An inquest report Exhibit P-K was prepared at 2-30 p.m. by Head Constable Maya Ram, P.W. 4. The case for the prosecution rests on the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh, Ex. P-H, and on the statement of Narvel Singh, P.W. 12,

facts.text: Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, was an eye-witness to the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution rests on the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh, Ex. P-H, and on the statement of Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, who was an eye witness to the occur- rence and on the statement made by the deceased to his father as to his assailant

facts.text: Punjab High Court reversed the order of acquittal by Additional Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the Punjab High Court reversing an order of acquittal by the Additional Sessions Judge, Amritsar. The appellant Bakshish Singh and his brother Gurbakshi Singh were tried

facts.text: Head Constable Maya Ram recorded dying declaration in Urdu though Bachhinder Singh spoke in Punjabi.

anchor.surface_text: Head Constable Maya Ram, P.W. 4, has admitted in cross-examination that Bachhinder Singh gave his statement in Punjabi but the form and the detailed account given in the statement, Exhibit P-H, would show that it was number the product of Bachhinder Singhs creation alone

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge rejected dying declaration on grounds that only father and brother present, and it was touched up.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge rejected the dying declaration made by Bachhinder Singh on two grounds that at the time of recording the dying declaration number only Bhagwan Singh, the father, and Narvel Singh, the brother of Bachhin- der Singh, were present but the police officer had actually made enquiries from them about the occurrence before he proceeded to record the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh de- ceased.

facts.text: Supreme Court held dying declaration authentic and voluntary, accepted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in our opinion companyrectly appreciated the evidence and was right in accepting the authenticity of the dying declaration.

issues.text: Whether the dying declaration Exhibit P-H is voluntary, authentic, and unprompted by any outside agency?

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge rejected the dying declaration made by Bachhinder Singh on two grounds that at the time of recording the dying declaration number only Bhagwan Singh, the father, and Narvel Singh, the brother of Bachhin- der Singh, were present but the police officer had actually made enquiries from them about the occurrence before he proceeded to record the dying declaration of Bachhinder Singh de- ceased.

issues.text: Whether recording the dying declaration in Urdu, when the deceased spoke in Punjabi, renders it unreliable or inadmissible?

anchor.surface_text: Another reason given by the Additional Sessions Judge for rejecting the dying declaration was that the deceased gave the narrative of events in Punjabi and the statement was taken down in urdu. In the Punjab that is how the dying declarations are taken down and that has been so ever since the companyrts were established

issues.text: Whether the dying declaration contains extraneous details outside the scope of section 32(1) of the Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit P-H, the dying declaration, is a long document and is a narrative of a large number of incidents which happened before the actual assault. Such long statements which are more in the nature of First Information Reports than recital of the cause of death or circumstances resulting in it are likely to give the impression of their being number genuine

issues.text: Whether the statement of Dr. Mahavir Sud was admissible under section 33 of the Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: The admissibility of the statement of Dr. Mahavir Sud was assailed by companynsel for the appellant on the ground that the companyditions laid down for the admissibility of statements under s. 33 had number been companyplied with and several decided cases were relied upon.

issues.text: Whether corroboration is essential for the efficacy of a dying declaration?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel then companytended that for the efficacy of the dying declaration, companyroboration was essential. In the present case there is the statement of Narvel Singh, P. W. 12, who is an eye witness to the occurrence which is relied upon by the prosecution as companyroboration of the dying declaration.

issues.text: Whether adverse inference can be drawn under section 114 of the Evidence Act for the prosecution's non-production of witness Sucha Singh?

anchor.surface_text: The number-production of Sucha Singh who is stated in the dying declaration and in the statement of Narvel Singh, P.W. 12, to have witnessed the occurrence was companymented upon by companynsel as a very serious omission. The Public Prosecutor stated at the trial that he was giving up Sucha Singh as he had been won over.

issues.text: Whether the High Court correctly applied the principles governing appeals against acquittal?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our opinion, have kept in view companyrect principles governing appeals against acquittals and have rightly applied them to the circumstances of this case.

Birhan Narain J., who delivered the main judg- ment, said This criticism appears to me to be without any substance. The statement was recorded by Head Constable Maya Ram who was posted in Amritsar and was number posted in village Kairon and therefore had numberknowledge of the parties number had any interest in them Thus there was numberreason why he should record the statement falsely or irregularly.

arguments.claim: Dying declaration voluntary without prompting as testified by Dr. Mahavir Sud

anchor.surface_text: Throughout the time that the statement was recorded Dr. Mahavir Sud of the Amritsar hospital was present. He has appeared as P.W. 17 in the present case. He is a respectable and disinterested person and he is positive in his testimony before the companyrt that the statement was made by the deceased voluntarily and that there was numberody present to prompt him.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our opinion, have kept in view companyrect principles governing appeals against acquittals and have rightly applied them to the circumstances of this case.

arguments.claim: Dying declaration should be limited to cause of death or circumstances per s.32(1) Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The dying declaration is the statement made by a person as to the cause of his death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death and such details which fall outside the ambit of this are number strictly within the permissible limits laid down by s. 32  1  of the Evi- dence Act

arguments.claim: Head Constable recorded dying declaration at deceased's dictation without addition or omission

anchor.surface_text: The Head Constable stated that the dying declaration was written at the declarants own dictation without any addi- tion or omission. In cross-examination numberhing was asked as to any questions having been put to the deceased by this witness.

arguments.claim: Questions by Head Constable to clarify ambiguities do not invalidate dying declaration

anchor.surface_text: Some criticism was levelled against the dying declaration based on a sentence in the statement of Dr. Mahavir Sud P. W. 17 that the Head Consta- ble put certain questions to clarify the ambiguities and these questions and answers do number find place in Exhibit P- H

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nce at that stage. Thereupon the learned trial judge ordered the statement to be transferred under s. 33 of the Evidence Act. He might have been well

arguments.court_reasoning: No such question put to Head Constable in cross; he denied additions

arguments.claim: Value of dying declaration disappears if supplied by others citing 1954 Lahore 805

anchor.surface_text: It is laid down in 1954 Lahore 805 that a dying declaration which records the very words of the dying man unassisted by interested persons is most valuable evidence but the value of a dying declara- tion altogether disappears when parts of it had obviously been supplied to the dead man by other persons

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ted that he did number allow any person to be present at that time. There is absolutely numberreason for doubting the companyrectness of this statemen

arguments.court_reasoning: Not applicable as no evidence of supplying; disinterested recorder and witness

holdings.text: The High Court correctly appreciated the evidence and was right in accepting the authenticity of the dying declaration, which was voluntary and made without prompting by any outside agency.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in our opinion correctly appreciated the evidence and was right in accepting the authenticity of the dying declaration. The statement of Maya Ram, P. W. 4, does not support the criticism of the learned trial judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Head Constable disinterested and from Amritsar, Dr. Mahavir Sud certified fitness and testified to voluntariness with no prompting; trial judge's criticism based on flawed premises rejected.

holdings.text: Recording the dying declaration in Urdu when given in Punjabi is standard practice in Punjab and not a ground for rejection or infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: the recording of the dying declaration in Urdu cannot be a ground for saying that the statement does not correctly reproduce what was stated by the declarant. This, in our opinion, was a wholly in.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical practice in Punjab courts and police since establishment; judicial authority never held it inefficacious.

holdings.text: Dying declarations should be confined to cause of death or circumstances under s.32(1) Evidence Act; extraneous details undesirable unless necessary for coherence, but authenticity judged per case circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The dying declaration is the statement made by a person as to the cause of his death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death and such details which fall outside the ambit of this are not strictly within the permissible limits laid down by s. 32 (1) of the Evidence Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long narratives resemble FIRs and arouse suspicion; desirable to frame rules limiting scope, but does not invalidate this declaration.

holdings.text: Statement of Dr. Mahavir Sud admissible under s.33 Evidence Act as witness unavailable without unreasonable delay and expense.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the learned judge transferred it on the ground of unreasonable delay and expense and we do not find any infirmity in this order of transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objection not raised earlier; summons returned unserved, inquiries confirmed unavailability; trial judge's order proper.

holdings.text: Corroboration is not essential as a rule of law for the efficacy of a dying declaration.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel then contended that for the efficacy of the dying declaration, corroboration was essential. In the present case there is the statement of Narvel Singh, P. W. 12, who is an eye witness to the occurrence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects contention; here corroborated by eye-witness Narvel Singh and father Bhagwan Singh, but not mandatory.

holdings.text: No adverse inference under s.114 Evidence Act can be drawn against the State for non-production of witness Sucha Singh who was won over.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecutor's discretion not to call won-over witness; would discredit prosecution; cites precedents; no oblique motive.

holdings.text: The High Court kept in view correct principles governing appeals against acquittals and rightly applied them.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge's erroneous view of dying declaration and oral evidence provided compelling reasons for reversal.

anchor.surface_text: The dying declaration is the statement made by a person as to the cause of his death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death and such details which fall outside the ambit of this are not strictly within the permissible limits laid down by s. 32 (1) of the Evidence Act
